meta.title: Demonstrate understanding of usability in human‑computer interfaces
meta.purpose: Students are able to demonstrate understanding of usability in human-computer interfaces.

grade_descriptors.N1: Evidence does not reach the minimum threshold for Achieved‑level indicators.
grade_descriptors.N2: Some Achieved‑level indicators are met, but not enough to satisfy all required Achieved criteria.
grade_descriptors.A3: All Achieved‑level indicators are met; no Merit‑level indicator meets the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.A4: All Achieved indicators are met and at least one Merit indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Merit threshold.
grade_descriptors.M5: All Achieved indicators are met and the Merit threshold is reached; no Excellence‑level indicator meets the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.M6: All Achieved indicators are met, all Merit indicators are met, and at least one Excellence indicator is met, but overall performance is below the Excellence threshold.
grade_descriptors.E7: All Achieved and Merit indicators are met and the Excellence threshold is reached, but not all Excellence indicators are met.
grade_descriptors.E8: All Achieved, Merit, and Excellence indicators are met.

omis.description: Describes the purpose of human‑computer interfaces
omis.detection_hint: Must clearly state what the interface helps the user achieve. Vague phrases like “it is useful” are insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The website helps students book library laptops.
The app lets users order food for delivery.

omis.description: Identifies and describes usability principles used in an interface
omis.detection_hint: Must name at least one usability principle and describe its use. Naming alone is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: It uses consistency so all pages have the same menu layout.
The system uses feedback by showing a loading spinner when pages are loading.

omis.description: Explains how usability principles have been applied in the interface
omis.detection_hint: Must link a named principle to a specific feature or behaviour. Restating definitions is not enough. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Help and documentation is provided through a 'Need Help?' popup that explains how to log in.
Error prevention is used by disabling the 'Submit' button until all fields are filled.

omis.description: Explains how the interface’s usability aids the user experience
omis.detection_hint: Must describe how the usability features support the user (e.g. clarity, speed, confidence). Saying 'it helps' without detail is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: The clean layout means users can find the reservation form quickly.
Feedback messages make it clear when a booking was successful.

omis.description: Compares the usability of human‑computer interfaces
omis.detection_hint: Must contrast two interfaces using specific principles. Listing differences without linking to usability is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Interface A used larger fonts and was easier to read than Interface B.
Both had search bars, but only Interface B used auto-complete to help users.

omis.description: Judges which interface used usability principles more effectively and explains why
omis.detection_hint: Must state which interface is better and give a reason using a principle. Opinions with no justification are insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Interface B was better because its consistent layout helped users feel confident.
Interface A used clearer feedback messages, so users knew their form was submitted.

omis.description: Suggests multiple usability‑based improvements for the interface
omis.detection_hint: Must propose at least two concrete improvements and link each to a usability principle. One unlinked suggestion is insufficient. Highlight the exact phrase(s) that satisfy or violate this indicator.
success_examples: Add a progress bar to improve feedback.
Use larger icons to help users with visual impairments.
